steps.title: Plant onions, and leave them in the ground for two years.
steps.content: Plant onions, and leave them in the ground for two years. Watch for flowers and then seed heads to form during the late summer of the second season. [1] X Research source You may wish to plant extra plants if you want onions to eat during the first season.

steps.title: Wait for the seed heads to dry.
steps.content: Wait for the seed heads to dry. Most of the flowers will be dry, and the seeds will begin to fall out on their own. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the seed heads, or umbels, from the plants and allow them to dry completely.
steps.content: Cut the seed heads, or umbels, from the plants and allow them to dry completely. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Separate the seeds from the stems and other matter that makes up the seed head.
steps.content: Separate the seeds from the stems and other matter that makes up the seed head. Many seeds will fall out on their own. For the rest, place them in a bag, pound the whole bag against a hard surface. [4] X Research source If you have many seeds, you may be able to use the wind to separate them from stems and other matter. Use a large bowl and toss them in the air, or pour them from one container to another in a light breeze. The wind should sift the lighter stems away and leave the heavier seeds to fall. There's no harm in having a little bit of stem or seed head in your seeds unless you are sprouting them. If you plant it along with the seeds, it will just decompose.

steps.title: Store the seeds in a cool, dry place.
steps.content: Store the seeds in a cool, dry place. [5] X Research source [6] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. Label the seeds with the year you saved them, or plant them immediately in a mild climate. Most seeds work best if they are used within one year of saving them [7] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. â€” you may get an acceptable germination rate the second year, though. To prolong the seeds viability, put them in a paper envelope to absorb the moisture and keep them in an airtight container in the fridge. [8] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021.
